query: 非洲目前有哪些医疗机构在工作

entities.description: A grouping of informational items including press releases, briefs, and advisories related to health emergency response and preparedness in Africa.
Various regional, continental, and global organizations working in partnership to support pathogen genomics and public health responses in Africa.

Medical supplies include vaccines, medicines, and cold chain equipment vital for immunisation and healthcare services. Partnership efforts have secured procurement and strengthened supply chains for these supplies in Africa.

GHIs refer to global partnerships and funding platforms such as Gavi, the Global Fund, and the Global Financing Facility that support health improvements and protection in Africa and worldwide.<SEP>Global Health Initiatives are international programs or coalitions that commit to procurement policies that prioritize buying medical products from Africa for Africa as part of supporting local production and health system strengthening."|>"The announcement of procurement commitments by Global Health Initiatives to buy in Africa for Africa

Unitaid is an international organization implementing the SafeBirth Africa program to improve access to innovative sexual and reproductive health commodities in Africa, funded under the EU Team Europe Initiative.

Northern Africa is a geographic region in Africa recognized as a distinct regional zone within various frameworks and initiatives. It plays a significant role in disaster and crisis management, as it is listed within the emergency response and preparedness framework. The region is a key focus area for public health strengthening under the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative and is actively involved in broader public health and continental strategy activities. Northern Africa is particularly important for pathogen genomic activities, which highlights its role in health surveillance and epidemiological research. Additionally, the region is concerned with Mpox preparedness efforts and is affected by mpox, participating in continent-wide coordination for preparedness and response actions. Northern Africa is also relevant to health surveillance and antimicrobial resistance monitoring efforts, underscoring its comprehensive involvement in various public health initiatives and regional health security measures.<SEP>Northern Africa is a region within Africa involved in health response activities coordinated by Africa CDC.<SEP>Northern Africa is among target areas for African Union-European Union health programs addressing pandemic prevention, vaccine production, and health systems resilience."|>"Region: Northern Africa
The Global Financing Facility supports country-led efforts to improve health and nutrition for women, children and adolescents, contributing to health improvements globally including Africa.
Around 38,000 health workers have been trained, equipped, and deployed across Africa through the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative to strengthen frontline public health response.

Botswana is a country in Africa recognized as part of the target area for medical and health emergency interventions.<SEP>Botswana is one of the five African Union Member States initially targeted to receive cold chain equipment to enhance vaccine storage and healthcare capacities.

The African Continent is the geographic focus of the health partnerships and initiatives described, encompassing diverse regions and countries collectively engaged to enhance health sovereignty, pandemic preparedness, and health system resilience."|>"Foundations of our cooperation with the African continent... to build resilient health systems... support global health internationally

APHF is an organization established to mobilize resources and investments for critical African public health activities in support of Africa CDC and the African Union’s New Public Health Order, focusing on resource mobilisation, grants management, advocacy, private sector engagement, and public health data analysis.<SEP>APHF is an organization partnering with Africa CDC to mobilize resources and support public health laboratory systems and initiatives in Africa, specifically to advance pathogen genomics and pandemic preparedness.

Africa is a continent facing a high burden of infectious diseases and antimicrobial resistance, with mortality rates from antimicrobial resistance surpassing those from HIV-AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. It experiences numerous humanitarian crises and disease outbreaks annually, making it the primary geographical focus of various public health initiatives such as the JEAP initiative. Africa is also served by WHO AFRO and is central to efforts aimed at enhancing public health emergency preparedness and response, particularly in the context of diverse emergencies that are exacerbated by factors like climate change and conflict. Overall, Africa remains the critical region for partnership efforts focused on improving public health emergency preparedness and addressing ongoing health challenges.<SEP>Africa is the continent targeted by the AVMA and related initiatives aiming to increase local vaccine production, improve health security, and strengthen health systems and manufacturing capacity across regions including Central, Eastern, Northern, Southern, and Western Africa."|>"The African Vaccine Manufacturing Accelerator is a Boon for the Continent... Region: Central Africa, Eastern Africa, Northern Africa, Southern Africa, Western Africa

entities.entity: Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response
entities.description: The activities and capabilities focused on anticipating, preparing for, and effectively managing public health emergencies in Africa.

Regional Emergency Hubs comprise three WHO-established centers in Africa (Dakar, Nairobi, Pretoria) created to improve rapid and effective responses to health emergencies, each with specialized functions including supply chain, medical personnel development, research, and genomic surveillance.

Critical medical and health emergency supplies prepositioned in the WHO regional hubs to enable rapid response during health crises. These include warehouse storage and management facilities located in Senegal and Kenya.

UNFPA collaborates with Unitaid in implementing the SafeBirth Africa program aimed at improving access to life-saving sexual and reproductive health commodities in Africa, supported financially by the EU Team Europe Initiative.

entities.entity: World Health Organization Regional Office for Africa
entities.description: The World Health Organization Regional Office for Africa (WHO AFRO) is a regional branch of the World Health Organization dedicated to supporting and improving public health across African Member States. WHO AFRO focuses on health and disease control, coordinating health initiatives, emergency preparedness, and response efforts throughout the African region. It leads various programs such as the Precision Public Health Metrics programme, which leverages data analytics for disease eradication and public health improvement. In addition to disease prevention and healthcare capacity-building, WHO AFRO plays a key role in shaping health financing strategies in Africa, exemplified by its convening of meetings to develop roadmaps for reshaping health financing on the continent. Through these efforts, WHO AFRO works to strengthen healthcare systems and promote sustainable health outcomes across Africa.
The African Union Development Agency-NEPAD is an AU agency focusing on socio-economic development programs including health, partnering in regulatory strengthening and local manufacturing efforts.

entities.entity: PATH (Program for Appropriate Technology in Health)
entities.description: Global health organization collaborating with Africa CDC and Clinton Health Access Initiative on vaccine supplier landscape analysis for Africa to inform manufacturing development.

Funding sources including national governments, private sector, civil society, external finance institutions and development partners aimed at financing sustainable investments in the health workforce across African countries as called for by the charter.

Africa Programme II is a United Kingdom-funded initiative investing £95 million to foster partnerships with African countries and organizations to tackle deadly diseases, epidemics, drug resistance, and climate-related health issues.
Private sector entities collaborating with Africa CDC and partners in public health initiatives including diagnostics and pathogen genomics.

Dr Moeti leads WHO AFRO and publicly acknowledges UK's commitments supporting health initiatives in Africa.<SEP>The WHO Regional Office for Africa is a branch of the World Health Organization dedicated to healthcare programs and initiatives supporting African countries, including the rollout of malaria vaccines across multiple countries in the African region.<SEP>The WHO Regional Office for Africa is a regional branch of the World Health Organization focused on health issues and initiatives within Africa, including launching health investment charters to address workforce shortages.
Genomic testing capacity expanded from 7 to 40 laboratories across Africa as a direct result of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, enhancing disease surveillance and outbreak response.
Over 600 COVID-19 vaccination centres across Africa were integrated into healthcare systems as part of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative to improve vaccine accessibility and distribution.

entities.entity: Africa Centre for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: A continent-wide public health institute focused on disease control and prevention in Africa, led by Dr Jean Kaseya, and engaged in advocating for strategic health investments.
An identified necessary increase in Africa's Gross Domestic Product expenditure on health, up to 1.5%, with over half dedicated specifically to health workforce investment.

entities.entity: African Centres for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: Africa CDC is a public health agency of the African Union tasked with supporting public health initiatives and disease prevention on the continent. It partnered in convening the meeting on health financing.

entities.entity: Medical Supplies and Cold Chain Equipment
entities.description: Medical Supplies and Cold Chain Equipment refers to essential materials and infrastructure used to transport and store medical products at controlled temperatures, critical for healthcare delivery in Africa.

Southern Africa is a geographic region in Africa that plays a significant role in regional health and emergency response initiatives, particularly concerning infectious disease outbreaks such as Mpox. It is actively involved in coordinated epidemic response and surveillance efforts, serving as a key area for disease intelligence and outbreak management. The region is part of various health emergency actions and preparedness efforts, including its inclusion in the implementation of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative. Additionally, Southern Africa is recognized as an important region for pathogen genomic activities, contributing to broader health strategies and outbreak response initiatives across the continent.<SEP>Southern Africa is a geographic region targeted in medical and health emergency initiatives by Africa CDC.<SEP>Southern Africa is included as a geographic focus for AU-EU health initiatives aiming to improve pandemic preparedness and advance health security."|>"Region: Southern Africa
Wellcome Trust is a global charitable foundation supporting health research and technical response efforts related to mpox outbreak in Africa.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency and specialized technical institution of the African Union. It is dedicated to supporting Member States across Africa in strengthening health systems by improving disease surveillance, emergency response, prevention, and control of diseases. Africa CDC focuses on enhancing the continent's capacity to detect, prevent, and respond to health emergencies, including combating deadly diseases such as drug-resistant infections and pandemics. Additionally, the agency plays a key role in communication and information dissemination related to health emergencies and outbreak response. Africa CDC also leads the African Union's public health initiatives, including pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response, aiming to build resilient health systems throughout Africa.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention is a continental public health agency collaborating closely with WHO and the regional emergency hubs to strengthen emergency preparedness and health systems in Africa.
A region in Africa supported by France for regional health projects aligned with Africa CDC’s priorities.

Eastern Africa is a geographic sub-region within the continent of Africa that plays a critical and multifaceted role in health surveillance, disease intelligence, and emergency response efforts. It is a focal area for public health initiatives, including preparedness and response activities for outbreaks such as mpox. The region is highly affected by visceral leishmaniasis (VL), accounting for 73% of global VL cases in 2022, making it the primary target of the newly launched VL elimination framework. Eastern Africa is also a key operational zone for humanitarian and development programs, notably the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, underscoring its importance in addressing crises and enhancing resilience.

In addition, Eastern Africa actively participates in advanced scientific efforts like pathogen genomic activities that support the monitoring and understanding of infectious diseases. The region benefits significantly from coordinated health emergency initiatives and medical response strategies, including its involvement in AU-EU health partnerships aimed at pandemic preparedness and health system strengthening. Overall, Eastern Africa is a vital region for emergency management, public health strategy, humanitarian initiatives, and genomic research, making it central to both regional and global health security efforts.

Namibia is a country in the African region that hosted the inauguration of the African Health Workforce Investment Charter and the Health Workforce Investment Forum, with active participation by its government officials.

entities.entity: WHO Regional Emergency Hub in Nairobi
entities.description: The WHO Regional Emergency Hub launched in Nairobi, Kenya in 2022 is the first emergency hub in Africa, focusing on the development of emergency medical personnel and reducing emergency response delivery times.
Organizations and entities that function as partners in implementing genomic surveillance projects and outbreak response activities across Africa.

A collective European Union effort to support various projects in Africa including strengthening pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity, with France as a major contributor.<SEP>Team Europe Initiatives are investment packages and collaborations under the EU Global Gateway strategy aimed at enhancing resilience and cooperation between Europe and Africa in health security, digital health, and public health institutes."|>"Today we launch three major Team Europe Initiatives on health security, digital health and public health institutes...

entities.entity: Ministers of Health of Angola, Benin, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, Uganda
entities.description: The Ministers of Health from multiple African countries including Angola, Benin, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, and Uganda, who convened in a high-level meeting in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on 13 April 2024 to address the mpox outbreak.
Africa PGI is a tag referring to the Africa Pathogen Genomics Initiative and related genomic surveillance activities in Africa.

Africa Health Research Organisation (AHRO) is a research organization focused on small drug molecules, clinical and academic research, and scientific publishing. It engages in behaviour research on obesity, offers various academic courses including nursing and midwifery, and hosts visiting scholars and students programs. AHRO manages governance structures such as the Board of Trustees and Governing Council, and emphasizes innovation in research methodologies.

Africa CDC (Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention) is the specialized, continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union dedicated to strengthening health institutions and capacities across Africa. Its primary mission is to enhance disease surveillance, outbreak response, and emergency preparedness to detect, prevent, control, and manage health threats throughout the continent. As a leading public health institution in Africa, Africa CDC plays a central role in building health security and coordinating regional responses to infectious disease epidemics, including mpox, by collaborating closely with African governments and global partners such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the European Union, and Gavi.

Africa CDC actively co-leads initiatives like the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to address disease outbreaks and public health emergencies, while providing technical support, capacity building, and epidemic response coordination. The agency emphasizes genomic surveillance strategies as part of its comprehensive approach to managing public health challenges and strengthening health systems continent-wide.

In addition to its role in disease control, Africa CDC leads and supports critical vaccine manufacturing initiatives, including the African Vaccine Manufacturing Alliance (AVMA), with the goal of increasing local production to meet 60% of Africa’s demand for vaccines, medicines, and diagnostics by 2040. The agency promotes sustainable vaccine development, regulatory harmonization, decentralization of diagnostics, and localization of health product manufacturing to build resilient and self-sufficient health systems.

Operating under the African Union's Agenda 2063 and guided by a strategic plan for 2023-2027, Africa CDC strives to enhance health sovereignty, improve health outcomes, strengthen emergency response capabilities, and foster knowledge-sharing and institutional strengthening across African countries. Through these efforts, Africa CDC empowers Africa’s health security and advances the continent’s ability to manage current and future public health threats effectively.

The African Union (AU) is a continental political and economic union comprising 55 African countries dedicated to fostering regional integration, political and economic collaboration, and inclusive growth across the continent. It provides frameworks, protocols, and agreements to coordinate health security and outbreak response, including cooperation on infectious diseases such as mpox. The AU supports policy coordination and development initiatives in partnership with regional communities and citizens, promoting peace and stability throughout Africa. It operates as a leading political organization under which the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) functions as an autonomous health agency, assisting member states in their public health efforts. The African Union actively engages in strategic international partnerships, notably with the European Union, to advance health initiatives focused on pandemic prevention, health security, strengthening health systems, and local vaccine manufacturing. Furthermore, the AU supports global health efforts such as the Gavi 2024 replenishment event in Paris and endorses accountability mechanisms like the Lusaka Agenda, highlighting its commitment to transparent and effective governance across the continent.<SEP>The African Union is a continental organization representing African countries, co-hosting the AVMA launch event and partnering with Africa CDC and Gavi to promote regional vaccine manufacturing and health security in Africa.

Uganda is a country in East Africa included in Africa CDC's regional health initiatives.<SEP>Uganda is an African country that benefited from vaccine purchases facilitated through the AVAT payment facility supported by France and Afreximbank.<SEP>Uganda is one of the African Union Member States initially supplied with cold chain equipment to boost vaccination programs and healthcare system capabilities.

entities.entity: Africa Launches Continental Strategy to Decentralize Diagnostics and Accelerate Outbreak Response
entities.description: An Africa CDC-led continental initiative aimed at improving decentralized diagnostic capabilities and speeding up outbreak response mechanisms across Africa.<SEP>This is a continental strategy launch event focused on decentralizing diagnostics and improving response to outbreaks in Africa.<SEP>This is a continental-level initiative aimed at decentralizing diagnostic services and speeding up responses to disease outbreaks across Africa.

entities.entity: Partnership for Public Health Emergencies Preparedness & Response
entities.description: A collaborative partnership focused on responding to public health emergencies in Africa, seeking 1 billion USD funding to improve preparedness, detection, and response to emergencies triggered by climate change and conflict-related disasters.
National and regional governments across African countries engaged in collaborations to support the implementation of pathogen genomic surveillance and outbreak response.

The United Nations Children's Fund is the first partner to join the JEAP partnership, contributing to efforts to transform health security on the African continent.<SEP>UNICEF is a global organization and the United Nations agency dedicated to children's welfare, operating in over 190 countries and territories. It focuses on supporting disadvantaged children worldwide through efforts related to child rights, health, immunization, community health programs, humanitarian action, and supply operations. In addition to its broad mission, UNICEF actively contributes to specific health initiatives such as supporting mpox response efforts in Africa alongside other international partners. The organization also plays a key role as an implementing partner in enhancing vaccine storage by procuring and delivering cold chain equipment in African Union Member States. Through these comprehensive activities, UNICEF strives to build a better world for all children.<SEP>UNICEF is an international organization working as a partner with WHO and others to support the malaria vaccine rollout efforts in African countries through coordination and resource mobilization.

The United Kingdom government has committed significant financial resources and partnerships aimed at advancing global health, supporting disease control and vaccine development initiatives, particularly in Africa and low- and middle-income countries.

Cameroon is an African country located in Central Africa that has recently taken significant steps in public health and disease control. Beginning on 22 January 2024, Cameroon started integrating the RTS,S malaria vaccine into its national routine immunization program, covering over 500 health facilities across 42 health districts in 10 regions. The country is actively involved within the scope of Africa CDC health-related strategies and outbreak responses, highlighting its engagement in continental health initiatives. Additionally, Cameroon is one of five African Union Member States initially targeted to receive cold chain equipment aimed at improving vaccine-storage infrastructure and immunization services. Furthermore, Cameroon has been included in the initial focus of Mpox research conducted by the Consortium, underscoring its role in emerging infectious disease studies in Africa.

The Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative is a USD 1.5 million partnership between the Mastercard Foundation and Africa CDC aimed at ensuring vaccine equity by purchasing and supporting vaccination delivery for millions in Africa.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health. It collaborates closely with various partners, including the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), the African Union, and European Union partners, to support and strengthen health systems and improve access to medicines in Africa. The WHO provides guidance under the International Health Regulations and actively supports responses to outbreaks such as mpox in Africa. Additionally, through initiatives like the Joint Emergency Action Plan (JEAP), the WHO works to enhance emergency preparedness and response capabilities across the African continent.

The African Medicines Agency (AMA) is a continent-wide regulatory body requiring the collective support of African member states to provide affordable, quality medicines and strengthen regulatory harmonization.<SEP>The African Medicines Agency is a continental regulatory body aimed at harmonizing and enhancing medicine regulation across Africa to improve access to safe and effective health products.

Africa CDC and UNICEF Expand Partnership to Strengthen Health Systems and Immunization of Children in Africa – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and UNICEF Expand Partnership to Strengthen Health Systems and Immunization of Children in Africa
Addis Ababa | NewYork, 29 February 2024 –
Today, the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and UNICEF announced an extended partnership dedicated to strengthening primary healthcare, supply chain management, pooled procurement and local manufacturing, and emergency response. The collaboration builds on the 2022-2024 Partnership Framework Agreement between Africa CDC and UNICEF, which aims to achieve the goals outlined in the African Union Agenda 2063: The Africa We Want. The partnership is expected to have a significant impact on public health in Africa by strengthening procurement and supply chain systems, with a particular focus on immunisation for children across the continent.
H.E Dr Jean Kaseya, Director General of Africa CDC, and Ted Chaiban, UNICEF Deputy Executive Director for Humanitarian Action and Supply Operations, signed the expanded partnership agreement in Addis Ababa.
The COVID-19 pandemic exposed the fragility of many healthcare systems and highlighted deficiencies and challenges in medical supply chains. While countries with strong primary healthcare systems were better able to cope, the disruption caused by the pandemic left others facing shortages of vital medical commodities. Over the next four years, Africa CDC and UNICEF will work together to establish robust institutional backing for supply chain management and enhance pooled procurement mechanisms to fortify Africa’s healthcare infrastructure, ensuring timely and adequate access to essential medical supplies for its population.
H.E Jean Kaseya expressed his pride in the partnership with UNICEF, stating that their shared commitments will enhance primary healthcare and strengthen Africa’s health security. ‘‘The partnership will optimise supply chain management, operationalise the pool procurement mechanism for Africa CDC, empower community health workers, and advance local manufacturing. Ultimately, these efforts will strengthen immunisation systems and reduce outbreaks and epidemics on the continent’’, he says.
Immunisation is one of the most effective public health interventions globally. However, millions of children in Africa are still deprived of life-saving vaccinations.
UNICEF’s The State of the World’s Children
2023: For Every Child
, Vaccination report revealed that 12.7 million children were under-vaccinated in 2021, including 8.7 million who did not receive a single dose, also called “zero-dose” children.
“This partnership is a commitment to the well-being of children and their families, affirming their right to health. By strengthening our partnership with Africa CDC and the Joint Emergency Action Plan for Africa, we can ensure communities get the support they need without delay,” said Ted Chaiban, UNICEF Deputy Executive Director for Humanitarian Action and Supply Operations. “The push forward on paid and protected community health workers, medical supplies made in Africa, for Africans, remains one of our highest priorities.”
During the past two years, UNICEF and Africa CDC have achieved significant milestones in strengthening Africa CDC’s institutional capacity and catalysing community health programmes, immunisation systems, emergency response, and supply chain enhancement. Collaborative efforts secured the procurement of COVID-19 vaccine doses and essential cold chain equipment for routine immunisation. Joint high-level advocacy initiatives focused on immunisation, community health, and response to public health emergencies.
Africa imports 99% of its vaccines and 70 to 90% of its medicines and medical devices, which is a significant challenge. Africa CDC aims to achieve sustainable production and supply of essential health commodities through African manufacturers, considered Africa’s second independence by Africa CDC. Africa CDC’s goal is to work with African Union Member States and partners to actively advocate for and support the procurement of vaccines made in Africa and prioritise initiatives that strengthen local manufacturing.
Through the Partnership for Vaccine Manufacturing, Africa CDC aims to manufacture 60% of the continent’s vaccine needs by 2040, paving the way toward robust and self-reliant health systems, ensuring that people can obtain and use health commodities when and where required.
The expanded partnership between Africa CDC and UNICEF signifies a concerted effort to address Africa’s pressing health challenges. By prioritising immunisation, strengthening health systems, and promoting local production, both organisations are poised to make tangible and sustainable impacts on the health and well-being of children and communities across the continent while safeguarding Africa’s health security.
#  #
About the Partnership
The Africa CDC and UNICEF Partnership Framework Agreement, commenced in 2022 and extended today to 2027, contributes to the goals and objective of Agenda 2063: The Africa We Want. The partnership framework outlines three programmatic areas of collaboration: (i) public health emergency preparedness and response; (ii) immunization systems strengthening; and (iii) procurement and supply chain systems strengthening. Under the partnership extension, this collaboration will expand, particularly in the areas of system strengthening for primary health care (including community health and nutrition systems), in supply chain management, regional and pooled procurement, manufacturing and emergency preparedness and response.
About Africa CDC
The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union that supports member states in their efforts to strengthen health systems and improve surveillance, emergency response, and prevention and control of diseases. Learn more at:
https://africacdc.org
About UNICEF
UNICEF works in some of the world’s toughest places, to reach the world’s most disadvantaged children. Across more than 190 countries and territories, we work for every child, everywhere, to build a better world for everyone. Learn more at www.unicef.org.
Media inquiries:
Communication and Public Information Directorate| Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention| Email:
Communications@africacdc.org|
Ricardo Pires| UNICEF New York | Tel: +1 917 631 1226 | Email

African health leaders begin work on roadmap to reshape global health financing on the continent | WHO | Regional Office for Africa
Skip to main content
WHO Africa
African health leaders begin work on roadmap to reshape global health financing on the continent
African health leaders begin work on roadmap to reshape global health financing on the continent
13 June 2024
Addis Ababa –
More than 80  ministry of health experts, regional and global partners and civil society representatives have set in motion the development of a roadmap to catalyse action to reshape the health financing ecosystem in Africa, and make it fit-for-purpose towards 2030 and beyond.
The meeting was convened by the World Health Organization’s (WHO) Regional Office for Africa, in partnership with the African Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the African Constituency Bureau of the Global Fund.
The development of the roadmap marks an important step in the ongoing process of identifying ways to ensure that global health initiatives (GHIs) and other external funding partners are more effective, efficient and equitable in complementing domestic financing, to strengthen health system capacities, accelerate progress towards universal health coverage (UHC), and deliver health impact.
Over the past two decades, GHIs such as Gavi, the Global Fund and the Global Financing Facility have contributed to enormous progress in protecting health and improving lives of people in Africa and across the world. However, important changes in health needs, financing and governance necessitate a renewed vision for how they support countries to deliver sustainable impact.
“With the growing need for strong and resilient health systems that can adapt to emerging threats, while continuing to meet existing health needs, the imperative of optimizing the impact of available resources is becoming increasingly urgent to advance Africa towards universal health coverage,” said Dr Matshidiso Moeti, WHO’s Regional Director for Africa.
Focusing on GHIs as an entry point and catalyst for change in the broader health financing ecosystem, the
Lusaka Agenda
, published on UHC Day on 12 December 2023, represented the culmination of a 14-month, multi-stakeholder process that captured consensus around five strategic shifts for the long-term evolution of GHIs. The roadmap for the implementation of the Lusaka Agenda implementation in Africa will set out priority actions to realize these shifts.
“At the 37th African Union (summit in February, African leaders endorsed the establishment of an accountability mechanism within the AU architecture to ensure effective implementation of the Lusaka Agenda on the continent. Our discussions over the past two days began to give shape to what this might look like,” said Dr Jean Kaseya, Director-General of Africa CDC.
The draft roadmap will be refined over the coming months, before it is presented for consideration by  ministers of health at the WHO Regional Committee for Africa, to be held in Brazzaville, Congo, in August this year.
“The Lusaka Agenda will ensure long-term sustainability and will propel countries towards achieving UHC,” said Dr Patrick Kuma-Aboagye, Director-General of the Ghana Health Service, and co-chair of the Lusaka Agenda Working Group.
To deliver more sustainable impact in the face of emerging threats such as climate change and conflicts, the key shifts highlighted in the Lusaka Agenda include a  focus on strengthening primary health care by bolstering health systems, catalysing action on domestic financing,  improving joint approaches to achieving health equity, and strategic and operational coherence among  GHIs. The Lusaka Agenda  also calls for  improved  coordination of approaches to products, reseach and development (R&D) and regional manufacturing, to address market and policy failures in global health.
“The Lusaka Agenda is now moving from talk to action, led by countries, and GHIs are listening,” added Linda Mafu, the Global Fund’s head of Civil Society and Political Advocacy.
Click image to enlarge
For Additional Information or to Request Interviews, Please contact:
Collins Boakye-Agyemang
Communications and marketing officer
Tel: + 242 06 520 65 65 (WhatsApp)
Email:
boakyeagyemangc
[at]
who.int
(boakyeagyemangc[at]who[dot]int)

,
H.E. Stella KYRIAKIDES
“
An ever-closer partnership between the African Union and the European Union is indispensable for public health. We want to work more closely with our African partners on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health and anti-microbial resistance, as well as the health effects of climate change. These are core objectives for our EU Global Health Strategy and the foundations of our cooperation with the African continent. We are now at a critical stage of the negotiations on the pandemic agreement and the international health regulations, with which we would provide new multilateral solutions to common challenges. The EU is committed to conclude the negotiations by May, a responsibility equally shared by all nations. I am pleased that the African Union and EU are joining voices and taking concrete steps to support global health internationally.
”
Africa CDC Director General,
H.E Dr Jean Kaseya
“As we navigate the complexities of global health, Africa is on the path towards self-sufficiency through equitable access to medical products. Africa’s target of producing 60% of vaccines by 2040 through the Africa CDC underscores our commitment to health sovereignty. Through strategic partnerships like the EU-AU collaboration, we accelerate our capabilities, leveraging expertise and resources to build resilient health systems and strengthen Pandemic preparedness.”
Specific outcomes of the high-level conference include the following concrete engagements:
Working Arrangement between Africa CDC and the European Commission to best implement the expanded strategic AU-EU Health partnership;
The European Commission and the Belgian Presidency announced additional TEI MAV+ funding for the advancement of the African Medicines Agency;
The announcement of procurement commitments by Global Health Initiatives to buy in Africa for Africa;
Three additional Team Europe Initiatives on health were launched: Health Security using a One Health approach, Digital Health, and Public Health Institutes;
The Team Europe Initiative (TEI) on Social Protection was launched;
Work product leads for Team Europe and Team Africa were confirmed;
A new programme ‘SafeBirth Africa’ to support improved access to innovative life-saving commodities for sexual and reproductive health in Africa. The programme will be implemented by Unitaid and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), supported by a financial contribution of €20 million from the EU budget under the Team Europe Initiative on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights that was launched in Kigali in December 2022;
An expanded AU-EU High Level Steering Meeting (HLSM) at DG-level will jointly oversee regional heath TEIs.
-END-

About AU IBAR
The African Union-Interafrican Bureau for Animal Resources (AU-IBAR) is a technical office under the African Union’s Department of Agriculture, Rural Development, Blue Economy, and Sustainable Environment (DARBE). Our mission is to support AU member states in harnessing the potential of livestock, fisheries, aquaculture, and wildlife for human well-being and economic growth. We promote the sustainable development and use of these resources to enhance nutrition, food security, and overall prosperity across the African continent. Learn more at:
www.au-ibar.org

About ASLM
The African Society for Laboratory Medicine (ASLM) is a pan-African professional body working to advocate for the critical role and needs of laboratory medicine and networks throughout Africa. ASLM aims to strengthen healthcare systems through collaborative efforts with governments, local and international organizations, implementing partners, and the private sector. Learn more at
www.aslm.org

Africa CDC and Mastercard Foundation launch phase 2 of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods (SLL) initiative to strengthen Africa’s public health systems – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and Mastercard Foundation launch phase 2 of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods (SLL) initiative to strengthen Africa’s public health systems
November 28, 2023,
Lusaka
– The Africa CDC and the Mastercard Foundation have entered a new phase of their partnership on the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative in the aftermath of WHO’s declaration of the end of COVID-19 pandemic as a public health emergency of international concern. The Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, a bold and unprecedented $1.5 billion partnership, was launched in June 2021. This innovative and ground-breaking partnership aimed to purchase COVID-19 vaccines, roll out vaccinations, build the vaccine manufacturing workforce for the continent, and strengthen the Africa CDC to ensure long-term health security for Africa.
Unprecedented in scale, speed and inclusion of African organisations, the partnership has
contributed to the continent’s current vaccination rate of 53 per cent of
the target population, up from just 3 per cent at the start of the initiative. The partnership has also trained, equipped, and deployed 38,000 health workers, creating a robust frontline in safeguarding public health locally. It has provided job opportunities for 23,000 individuals and integrated over 600 COVID-19 vaccination centres into healthcare systems. Additionally, this initiative led to the expansion of genomic testing capabilities from seven to 40 laboratories across the continent.
The review of Phase 1 of this initiative, among fifteen implementing partners across 29 countries, conducted by Deloitte, indicates that the vast majority of funds disbursed were used effectively and as intended. Likewise, ongoing monitoring by KPMG has confirmed that partners not only showed strength in programmatic results but also improved the institutional capacity for greater sustainability and institutional resilience.
“Our Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative with the Mastercard Foundation has shown the power of respectful and action-oriented partnerships rooted in collaboration, coordination and systems strengthening. The experience and learnings from Phase I will enable us to move with greater speed and scale to deliver with accelerated impact to our member states” said
Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director General of the Africa CDC
.
In its second phase, the partnership will expand its scope and scale, focusing on completing the vaccination of healthcare workers and vulnerable groups, building a robust workforce of community health workers, ensuring pandemic preparedness by bolstering national public health institutions, laboratory capacities, data access and quality, local manufacturing of vaccines, therapeutics and diagnostics, and continuing strengthening of Africa CDC.
“While the global pandemic may be declared over, the need to continue investing in our health systems, build our workforce and prepare for future pandemics remains urgent. This partnership will ensure that we have strong health institutions and systems. We aim to enable thousands of young people to build their careers in healthcare and contribute to improving lives in Africa,” said
Reeta Roy, President, and CEO of the Mastercard Foundation.
The Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative stands out as a testament to the power of African-led health solutions. As it progresses to its next phase, partnerships will continue to play a crucial role in shaping a New Public Health Order for Africa. Africa CDC and the Mastercard Foundation remain committed to improving the health and well-being of all Africans.
-ENDS-
About the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
Africa CDC is a continental autonomous health agency of the African Union established to support public health initiatives of Member States and strengthen the capacity of their public health institutions to detect, prevent, control, and respond quickly and effectively to disease threats. For more information, please visit:
https://africacdc.org
About the Mastercard Foundation
The Mastercard Foundation is a registered Canadian charity and one of the largest foundations in the world. It works with visionary organisations to advance education and financial inclusion, enabling young people in Africa and Indigenous youth in Canada to access dignified and fulfilling work. Established in 2006 through the generosity of Mastercard when it became a public company, the Foundation is an independent organisation separate from the company, with offices in Toronto, Kigali, Accra, Nairobi, Kampala, Lagos, Dakar, and Addis Ababa. Its policies, operations, and program decisions are determined by the Foundation’s Board of Directors and leadership. For more information on the Foundation, please visit
www.mastercardfdn.org
.

populations;
e. Sharing of information on potential threats to health security arising in areas affected by mpox outbreaks;
f. Monitoring the movement of people, animals and goods across national borders in accordance with the International Health Regulations (2005);
g. Capacity building of human resources, including joint training, learning exchanges and benchmarking visits, as well as simulation exercises;
h. Development of legal and regulatory processes and logistical planning for rapid cross-border deployment of public health experts and medical personnel for the mpox response.
3. FACILITATE technical support through Africa CDC and WHO mechanisms at various levels, including headquarters offices (Africa CDC and WHO), regional collaborating centres, regional offices and country offices.
4. EXCHANGE information rapidly on preparedness and response matters of common interest in line with the IHR (2005), in order to maintain the peace, security and prosperity of affected Member States and the Continent as a whole;
5. DECIDE to establish the Africa Taskforce for Mpox Coordination among Member States affected and at-risk of mpox to:
a. Facilitate the strengthening of preparedness and response capacities to mitigate the impact of mpox in Africa and beyond;
b. Strengthen rapid epidemic response, effective surveillance, capacity building of national laboratories and engagement with affected communities
c. Develop a common regional and national roadmap outlining mpox prevention, detection and control;
d. Prioritize scientific research and evidence synthesis for a better understanding of the disease, and support evidence-based decision-making for disease prevention and control.
6. REQUEST the African Union Commission, Africa CDC and WHO to jointly facilitate coordination of the Africa Taskforce for Mpox Coordination;
7. CALL UPON ALL partners to harmonize support to Member States in the fight against mpox by interacting with the African Taskforce for Mpox Coordination to ensure that each fulfills the mandates given to them at this meeting.
Kinshasa, 13 April 2024
